awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Neurofilament Transport Kinetics and Axonal Morphology
awd_abstract_narration:
Nerve cells communicate by sending electrical impulses along thin protrusions called axons.  One mechanism by which animals increase velocity of electrical impulses is to expand axons' cross-sectional area.  This expansion is caused by an accumulation of microscopic space-filling protein polymers called neurofilaments, which are transported into axons where they form a dynamic scaffold. This collaborative project will use microscopic imaging in conjunction with computational modeling to test the hypothesis that neurofilament accumulation in axons is caused by a slowing of neurofilament transport, much as cars pile up on highways when the traffic slows. This project will provide a rigorous and quantitative framework that relates the size and shape of axons, which is a key influence on their electrical properties, to the motile behavior of their internal constituents.  This work will also shed light on the mechanism by which neurofilaments accumulate abnormally and excessively within axons in many neurodegenerative diseases.  

This project will provide a unique training opportunity at the interface of computational and experimental biology for students with diverse backgrounds in the physical and life sciences. An emphasis will be placed on mentoring undergraduates lacking prior research experience, including women and minorities, through annual Research Experiences for Undergraduates fellowships. The investigators will also reach out to undergraduates by participating together in the Research for Undergraduates: Adventures in Mathematical Biology and its Applications curriculum at Ohio State University, which is an NSF-funded Undergraduate Biology and Mathematics program, and by serving as joint mentors in the Undergraduate Summer Research Program of the NSF-funded Mathematical Biosciences Institute at Ohio State University. Lastly, a neurofilament wiki page will be developed featuring information and resources on mathematical modeling of axonal transport to support these outreach activities and to facilitate the exchange of data between the two laboratories.

por.por_cntn:
The human brain is made of billions of neurons and brain function involves communication between many neurons. Proper brain function requires that the neuronal signals arrive at their targets at the right time which requires that the conduction speed of nerve fibers must match their physiologic function. This conduction speed is determined by a number of factors, but, most importantly, the caliber of the axon. Hence, regulation of axon caliber is essential for brain function. Yet, the mechanisms by which such regulation occurs have remained largely elusive.  In this project first steps have been made to develop tools to close this important gap of knowledge. The team of researchers who conducted this research consists of biologists and physicists drawing from diverse expertise towards solving this biologic problem.

The key hypothesis was that the mechanisms for regulating axon caliber are uniquely determined by the fact that the space-filling structures in the axon, the neurofilaments, are in perpetual motion and that therefore a local decrease of their velocity should give rise to a local increase in axon caliber, and, vice versa, a local increase of their velocity should give rise to a decrease in axonal caliber.  The goal of the project was to demonstrate such a hypothesized mechanism in myelinated axons. In the myelinated sections, the internodes, the axons are fat, but at the nodes of Ranvier, where the myelin is not present, the caliber of the axon is often much smaller. In order to demonstrate the hypothesized mechanism, the transport velocity of neurofilaments and the neurofilament content had to be determined in nodes of Ranvier and the internodes.  The team has developed a number of unique methods, the pulse-escape methods, which combine photoactivated fluorescence video imaging and computational modeling, to extract the kinetic parameters of neurofilament transport, including the transport velocity. The computational analysis is based on a mathematical model of neurofilament transport. Applying this method to myelinated axons, the team was able to demonstrate that the velocity of neurofilaments at nodes of Ranvier is indeed larger and matches the changes of neurofilament content between nodes and internodes.

It was also shown that the nodal constrictions of myelinated fibers are of important significance for axonal physiology because they reduce the axonal volume required to achieve a given target conduction velocity. In this way, nodal constrictions maximize the spatial and metabolic efficiency of these long processes.  

The combination of high speed recordings of moving neurofilaments and computational modeling have revealed insights into molecular perspectives of their motility. It was found that neurofilaments exhibit bidirectional motion suggesting the presence of molecular motors of both directionality and that a asymetric tug-of-war between these motors drives the neurofilaments, determining their velocity, axon caliber and hence neuron function.

The significance of the research goes far beyond its immediate scope. Insights into the interplay of neurofilament transport, axon morphology and nerve function may play a significant role for the understanding of neurodegenerative diseases associated with axonal swelling, and possibly, for the development of therapeutic targets associated with these diseases. This project was conducted by a team of physicists and neurobiologists and offered highly interdisciplinary opportunities in education and research for graduate and undergraduate students in physics and biology. Physics graduate students at Ohio University participating in the project, interacted directly with students from the collaborating neurobiology lab at Ohio State University. They have acquired at Ohio University a unique set of skills which will serve them well in an increasingly interdisciplinary research environment.
